node.title: Art We Saw This Fall
node.alt: Betsy Damon performing “7,000 Year Old Woman” on Prince Street, New York, May 21, 1977, archival print.
node.description: From our critics, reviews of closed gallery shows around New York City.
node.content: ["For the artist Betsy Damon, the 1970s were a time for rediscovery: During that decade, she found the feminist movement, left her husband and came out as a lesbian. She also began performing by covering herself in small bags filled with flour and painting her body and hair white, with blackened lips. She called herself the \u201c7,000 Year Old Woman\u201d (1977-78) and walked slowly in a spiral while cutting open the bags with scissors, symbolically freeing herself from the burdens of patriarchy.", "Damon has been an eco-artist and activist since the 1990s. Her show \u201cBetsy Damon \u2014 Passages: Rites and Rituals,\u201d curated by Monika Fabijanska, spotlights her early feminist performances. Represented mostly by photographs and written recollections, they are radical relics of a time when many artists from oppressed groups were finding their voices through experimentation. Damon\u2019s work seems almost like creative consciousness-raising. In \u201cA Shrine for Everywoman\u201d (1980-88), women were invited to write down their stories and place them in small bags, which were strung up like flags to demarcate a space of communion.", "It can be hard to grasp the power of Damon\u2019s pieces secondhand, but what comes through is her embrace of vulnerability and commitment to community. She opened herself up and challenged others to as well \u2014 and the photos suggest that she succeeded. One picture shows a group of people watching her performance \u201cBlind Beggarwoman\u201d (1979-80) on Wall Street. They seem to regard the art with skepticism but are also transfixed, a reluctant audience unwilling to look away. JILLIAN STEINHAUER", "Born in Mexicali, Mexico, Reynaldo Rivera was in California as a teenager in the mid-1970s. There, working on fruit farms and in canneries, he found a camera and taught himself how to use it. He settled in Los Angeles and began photographing the local rock music scene, but found his most absorbing subject in the city\u2019s drag bars, particularly those that drew a Latino audience.", "\u201cKiss Me Deadly,\u201d his New York solo debut at Reena Spaulings, is made up largely of black-and-white pictures of those bars and their performers: Miss Alex at the Silverlake Lounge; Melissa and Gaby at La Plaza, and Yoshi, the proprietor/star of Club Mugy\u2019s. What distinguishes Rivera\u2019s view of the performers is that he takes them seriously, lets them look as glamorous \u2014 as funny, gorgeous, too-much \u2014 as they wanted to be, and were. He\u2019s not an outsider looking in, but an insider capturing a world he knows and loves.", "It\u2019s good that he did capture it, because the club life of that time \u2014 the 1980s and \u201990s \u2014 is mostly gone. Gentrification, drugs and AIDS took it out. If you want to get a deep sense of it, I highly recommend a book of the artist\u2019s work, simply titled \u201cReynaldo Rivera\u201d and published in 2020. Edited by Hedi El Kholti and Lauren Mackler, it has many more pictures than in the show. It also includes valuable essays by Luis Bauz and Chris Kraus, and a lengthy email exchange between Rivera and the artist-performer Vaginal Davis, a vital veteran of the history that this photographer has preserved. HOLLAND COTTER"]
